title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as such. The Congress recognizes the importance of adequate nurse staffing levels for patient safety and outcomes. Despite evidence supporting this, there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, leading to job dissatisfaction and the use of mandatory overtime. This results in nurses working in a state of fatigue, impacting patient care. Limitations on mandatory overtime will ensure that health care facilities operate in a manner that safeguards public safety, guarantees quality health care services, and facilitates nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Nurses cannot be required to work beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Nurses cannot be required to work beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period, with exceptions during declared states of emergency for providers expected to deliver exceptional medical services to the community. During declared states of emergency, nurses cannot be mandated to work beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. Nurses have the right to report violations of these provisions to the Secretary, who will investigate complaints filed by nurses. Nurses are protected from being penalized for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations of labor laws. The Secretary can require providers to establish a plan of action to address violations and may impose civil money penalties. The text chunk discusses protections for nurses who report violations or refuse mandatory overtime. Providers cannot retaliate against nurses for reporting violations or refusing to work overtime. The text chunk outlines the requirements for providers of services to post notices specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file complaints with the Secretary for violations. The text outlines the requirement for providers of services to post nurse schedules and make them available to nurses upon request. The Secretary may impose civil money penalties for violations, with more severe penalties for repeated violations. The Secretary may impose civil money penalties on providers of services for violations, with details of penalties published online. Penalties imposed on providers under previous ownership will not be published after a 1-year period. In this subsection, definitions for mandatory overtime, overtime, and nurse are provided. Mandatory overtime refers to hours worked beyond specified limits, with potential adverse consequences for refusal. Overtime is defined as time worked exceeding specified periods. A nurse is defined as a registered professional. The term 'nurse' refers to a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse. The term 'provider of services' includes various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, outpatient departments, clinics, and home health agencies. 'Declared state of emergency' signifies an officially declared state of emergency by the Federal Government or appropriate state or local authority. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to recognized professional standards for nurses. The amendments made by this section will take effect 1 year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing patient care. The study will consider various factors and recommend maximum work hours. Additionally, a report on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities will be conducted. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for implementing policies on overtime requirements for nurses in federally operated medical facilities.
